image.altText: A large green toll shop is docked in the port of Burnie, while workers with machinery unload it.

props.synopsis: Tasmania's port operator is facing problems at both ends of the state with ageing infrastructure, including some over 100 years old, leading to safety concerns and costly upgrades.

title.children: Tasmania is a state reliant on shipping, but outdated wharf infrastructure is causing challenges

image.altText: A woman swimming in the marathon

props.synopsis: Australia has added to its medal tally in the first event on day 13, with Moesha Johnson winning silver in the women's 10km marathon swim. Follow live.

title.children: Moesha Johnson wins silver in marathon swim to begin day 13

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Swimming: Two Australians hunting medals in women's 10km swim

image.altText: Yes campaign for Indigenous Voice to Parliament launches

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian fund set up for "community purposes" gave $558,000 of taxpayer monies to a group backing the Yes campaign, an audit has revealed, with the Tasmanian government saying the use of public funds for political purposes "does not meet community expectations".

title.children: A group backing the 'Yes' campaign received $558k public grant, but the process had 'shortcomings', audit finds

image.altText: A woman in an australia vest holds a flag in the air and cries

props.synopsis: Australia has broken the record for most ever gold medals it has won during an Olympics. The milestone was reached on its best-ever day for medal wins. Here's how it unfolded.

title.children: Australia topples its gold record in most successful Olympics ever

image.altText: a large ferry with red livery in the sea.

props.synopsis: The ongoing saga of Tasmania's new ferries has charted yet another course, with it being revealed the bigger ships won't be able to operate at full capacity because the ships will sit too low at their temporary berth.

title.children: The new Spirit of Tasmania ferries unable to run at full capacity for years due to port upgrade delay

image.altText: Qantas CEO Alan Joyce speaks to the media during a press conference.

props.synopsis: Qantas has reduced former chief executive Alan Joyce's multi-million-dollar payout by almost $10 million.

title.children: Former Qantas chief executive Alan Joyce's multi-million-dollar payout reduced by almost $10 million

image.altText: Vanessa Amorosi walking out of the supreme court with a serious look

props.synopsis: Australian songbird Vanessa Amorosi has emerged victorious in the bitter court battle against her mother, who she sued after the pair had a dramatic falling out over her fortune.

title.children: Vanessa Amorosi emerges victorious in property court battle against her mother

image.altText: Adam Britton stands by greenery wearing a green shirt

props.synopsis: Adam Britton, a once-celebrated zoologist, has been sentenced to 10 years and five months in prison for bestiality and animal cruelty crimes.

title.children: Crocodile expert Adam Britton sentenced to more than 10 years in prison for bestiality and animal cruelty

image.altText: George Mills, Vinesh Phogat and David Ahman

props.synopsis: An Indian wrestler was cruelly denied a shot at winning a gold medal, tempers flared as a cameraman caused chaos during the 5,000m heats and the Swedish men booked themselves into the volleyball medal rounds courtesy of a little-known move. Here are your quick hits from day 12 of the Paris Olympics.

title.children: Olympic quick hits: Heartbreak for Indian wrestler, cameraman wanders into a race and Sweden's crafty volleyball tactic

image.altText: A group of protesters walking through a street

props.synopsis: Far-right demonstrations anticipated by police in dozens of locations across Britain fail to materialise, as peaceful anti-racism protesters instead show up in force.

title.children: British police prepared for far-right agitators. They found peaceful anti-racism protesters instead

image.altText: Kamala Harris and Tim Walz both smiling broadly in a stadium

props.synopsis: In the hours since Tim Walz was announced as the Democratic vice-presidential pick, Republicans have been launching attacks to tarnish his image, labelling him "dangerously liberal".

title.children: 'A radical leftist' who is 'heavy into transgender': Will Trump's attacks on Walz work?

image.altText: A young girl holds a number of charm bracelets wearing a sequin skirt.

props.synopsis: Experts say large-scale concert venues are a "matter of opportunity" for political extremists.

title.children: A Taylor Swift concert is a place of fun and excitement for young girls. It's also an appealing terror target

image.altText: A composite picture of a serious-looking woman and a smiling man surrounded by children.

props.synopsis: The Reserve Bank will not look favourably on the government's decision to boost childcare wages given its growing inflation fears, according to a former assistant governor.

title.children: Reserve Bank unlikely to cheer on childcare wage rise, says former deputy

image.altText: Gun seized by Tasmania Police

props.synopsis: A sub-machine gun, double-barrel 12-gauge shotgun and a homemade weapon are among the firearms seized by Tasmania Police this past month.

title.children: Submachine gun fired in hotel room among dozens of firearms seized in Tasmania

image.altText: Men in military attire holding shields with a person and a dog appearing behind them

props.synopsis: As Israel faces the prospect of a dangerous multi-front war, there are also growing internal divisions over the alleged abuse and torture of Palestinian detainees by Israeli forces.

title.children: Protesters fight to keep Israel's 'Abu Ghraib' open as graphic footage appears to show sexual assault of detainee

props.synopsis: Mounting scandals involving Buddhist monks are eroding public faith in a key pillar of Thai society.

title.children: A Thai monk embezzled $12 million in cash and gold. Then he made a rookie error

image.altText: Blue neon 'secure parking' sign in front of a car park

props.synopsis: Secure Parking was pursued in the Federal Court by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC), over its "Secure-a-Spot" service. The service falsely claimed over a period of five years that parking spots would be reserved for customers.

title.children: Parking giant fined nearly $11m following 'significant number of complaints' over reservation service

image.altText: Screengrab of a grey-haired man being wrestled into a car by a few policeman

props.synopsis: Jack Karlson, the man who spurred an iconic Australian meme after his infamous arrest outside a Brisbane restaurant, has died aged 82.

title.children: Jack Karlson, known for 'succulent Chinese meal' viral meme, dies aged 82

image.altText: A group of men wearing muslim garbs with khmanei in the middle looking over two coffins with the palestinian flag

props.synopsis: Israelis are on edge awaiting a response to two high-profile assassinations, but Iran is facing a near-impossible task of calibrating what it should be.

title.children: Iran vowed revenge on Israel and then went strangely silent. Here's what they might be up to

image.altText: Taylor and Dutton on the floor of the lower house. Dutton, out of focus, looks at Taylor as he speaks.

props.synopsis: Originally panning the federal government's plan to subsidise critical mineral projects as "billions for billionaires", the Coalition is now jostling to land a united position on the signature policy.

title.children: Dutton and Taylor at odds on taxpayer subsidies for critical minerals

image.altText: A portrait of Marcia Langton, an elderly Indigenous woman with long white hair, painted against a vivid indigo sky.

props.synopsis: Angus McDonald has won the People's Choice award for the Archibald Prize for his portrait of Marcia Langton.

title.children: A portrait of 'one of our greatest ever thinkers' wins the Archibald People's Choice award

image.altText: Two politicians stand and chat in front of flags

props.synopsis: New Zealand's prime minister Chris Luxon had insinuated Australians are stupid in a joke in parliament.

title.children: Albanese shrugs off 'incredibly simple' Australian sledge from Kiwi PM

image.altText: Nina Kennedy pulls a determined face while holding an Australian flag

props.synopsis: Nina Kennedy has had to fight for every inch of her glittering career, and having conquered the demons that threatened to derail her, she is the perfect athlete to earn Australia's record-breaking gold.

title.children: Overcoming her past demons, Nina Kennedy was the perfect person to lift Australia to its greatest ever Olympic heights

image.altText: Separate close-up headshots of Tim Walz and JD Vance.

props.synopsis: Tim Walz, a conservative-looking progressive, has a backstory that is so quintessentially small-town America, it feels almost made-up.

title.children: The 'hillbilly' vs the hunter: How America's VP candidates will battle for the heartland

image.altText: a man wearing a dark collared t-shirt in an office

props.synopsis: A senior employee of a prominent Alice Springs independent school has been arrested over the alleged assaults of multiple children, with several media outlets naming him as Yipirinya School principal Gavin Morris.

title.children: Prominent principal of Alice Springs school arrested for allegedly assaulting children

image.altText: Close up head shot of Elizabeth Taylor on a white backdrop

props.synopsis: The Lost Tapes allows audiences a look into Taylor's remarkable life in her own words, through never-before-heard interviews and rare archival footage.

title.children: Elizabeth Taylor reflects on her 'horrendous mistakes' and run-in with the Vatican in new documentary

image.altText: A board at the Australian Securities Exchange showing red and green stocks during trade.

props.synopsis: Qantas shares drop after former chief executive Alan Joyce's multi-million-dollar payout was cut by almost $10 million following a governance review. Catch up on the day's events as they unfolded on our markets blog.

title.children: Qantas shares drop after former CEO Alan Joyce's pay docked $9.2m — as it happened

image.altText: Aerial shot of dozens of houses in neat rows in a new outer-suburban housing estate.

props.synopsis: The Reserve Bank governor's public declaration was intended to remove any expectation of rate relief for the remainder of this year. It's a reality check that landed with a thud.

title.children: The Reserve Bank governor has delivered a reality check on rates. It landed with a thud

image.altText: A woman appears on a large screen delivering a speach from a lecturn in front of an audience.

props.synopsis: Australia's first Indigenous allyship summit hears concerns the prime minister is walking back on his commitment to set up an independent Makaratta truth-telling commission.

title.children: Indigenous summit told social media is fuelling polarisation amid push for truth-telling commission

image.altText: A composite image of Lauren Jackson at the 2000 and 2024 olympics

props.synopsis: Will Opals coach Sandy Brondello take Lauren Jackson out of cotton wool for a must-win crack at the might of the United States in their Olympic semifinal in Paris?

title.children: Lauren Jackson's ready for one last USA dance in Paris semi — if she's taken out of cotton wool, that is

image.altText: Kerry and Randall as children

props.synopsis: The Queensland government will launch an investigation into a Brisbane mental health institution following reporting by the ABC into historical allegations of abuse at the facility.

title.children: Investigation launched into Brisbane mental health facility after ABC reporting into historical abuse allegations

image.altText: A sketch of Patrick wearing a white shirt sitting against a grey background.

props.synopsis: An "unprecedented" amount of evidence is causing delays in court for the matter of Patrick Orren Stephenson, accused of murdering Ballarat woman Samantha Murphy.

title.children: Court hearings for man accused of murdering Samantha Murphy delayed due to 'huge' evidence brief

image.altText: A woman standing near a home, holding a gun.

props.synopsis: A senior specialist police officer tells an inquest gunshots fired by extremists, who killed two constables at Wieambilla in 2022, were "like nothing experienced before".

title.children: SERT operator tells Wieambilla inquest of Nathaniel Train's 'last stand' to fire police officer's gun
